07945.description: Description Use what you have learned in the classroom to help improve the quality of life for hospice patients. Utilize free time to be compassionate and genuine in order to reduce terminally ill patients’ loneliness and isolation. Please help us keep our patients happy and comfortable as they reach the end of their life due to a variety of health conditions including: cancer, Alzheimer’s, etc. How can you benefit by being a volunteer? Build your resume: Volunteer experience shows proof of motivation, commitment, initiative, dependability, and flexibility Develop interpersonal skills Increase meaning and purpose in your life Experience significant opportunities for growth and development Responsibilities of Companion volunteers: Contribute to our patients' quality of life Attend to Patients' Needs Communicate with Nurses by keeping them Up to Date about each Patient visited Maintain Patients' Confidentiality Travel and Visit patients in facilities in an area near you Read to them, give hand massage, assist in life review or memory building We offer you: FREE TB test and MMR Titer Extremely flexible assignments (anytime you can give is greatly appreciated) Convenient Orientation and FREE training and that fits your schedule Receive Internship Credit (if applicable-unpaid)
07945.title: Great Opportunity for Healthcare Students!

07940.description: Tutor and Mentor 12th grade students on math and writing skills.
07940.title: Tutor and Mentor in Madison

07940.description: We are looking for academic tutors, as well as squash volunteers in Madison, NJ! StreetSquash-Newark is an academic and athletic after-school program serving students in the 7th-12th grade. We are looking for volunteer tutors, and volunteer squash players for all weekdays in Montclair. Tutors: StreetSquash Newark Academic Tutors work with 1-2 students during after-school homework sessions. Our tutors assist 9th - 12th-grade students with math, English, history and science homework. These sessions occur from 3:45-6:00 pm every weekday at Drew University under the supervision of our Academic Director. Squash Coaches: StreetSquash Newark Volunteer Squash Players join StreetSquash students on the courts for basic drills, training, and games. Squash players of all levels are needed for our practice from 3:45-6:00 pm every weekday at Drew University. These sessions are led and supervised by our Squash Director. The best thing about becoming a StreetSquash volunteer is meeting great young people and making a difference in their lives - whether you can make it once a week or once in awhile, we encourage you to get involved. Please contact us with your interest and availability to tutor in our academic sessions, or to assist with Squash practices! If you are interested in volunteering with StreetSquash Newark at our Drew University facility, please complete our volunteer application here: http://streetsquash.org/newark/volunteer/. If you have questions, please e-mail Bomaya at bomaya@streetsquashnj.org or call 973.848.9600.
07940.title: Change a life- become a tutor or squash coach!

07940.description: Are you a lover of the arts? Our volunteers learn what goes on behind the scenes and front of house! Volunteering with us is also a great opportunity to build your résumé, fulfill a community service requirement, or just to be a part of the theatre scene! In return for their work, volunteers receive a ticket voucher which is redeemable for admission to the Theatre’s productions throughout the season. Volunteers may also receive community service hours for volunteering at The Shakespeare Theatre of New Jersey. Volunteering with us provides immeasurable experience helping people of all demographics, and reinforces the importance of responsibility and expedience in all aspects of life. The Shakespeare Theatre of New Jersey has a strong, committed Volunteer Corps that assists with our Front of House duties. The volunteers are extremely important in making the overall experience of the patrons enjoyable. Regular volunteer opportunities are available May through December, and we have no minimum requirement on volunteer hours. During shows our volunteers assist House Management with the following tasks: Greet and welcome patrons. Distribute programs and escort patrons to their seats. Serve concession items (coffee, soft drinks, snacks) in an expedient and friendly manner. Assist patrons with gift shop selections. Be familiar with Theatre productions, activities and programs. If you are interested in joining our volunteer team or have any questions please email volunteers@shakespearenj.org for more information! We look forward to hearing from you!
07940.title: Volunteer with us!
07940.org: THE SHAKESPEARE THEATRE OF NEW JERSEY INC

07940.description: Spending time with youth is a fun and rewarding experience. While mothers are attending a Dress For Success seminar to build the skills needed for a new job or interview, volunteers are needed to watch over the children. Arts & crafts, reading stories, homework help and playing games are just a few of the fun possibilities volunteers can engage in with the children. Ages range from 7 - 17 and the total number of youth can reach up to 15. NOTE: To participate in this project you must be a Jersey Cares volunteer. To sign up as a Jersey Cares volunteer: 1. Visit www.jerseycares.org 2. Click on \"Log-In\" 3. Click on \"Not a Member? Register\" 4. Fill out all necessary information. 5. Register for a project!
07940.title: Kiddy Care in Madison

06880.description: Volunteer at this fun family-friendly event that celebrates and raises funds for individuals with developmental disabilities and their families, friends, staff and supporters. Assist with set-up, takedown, lunch/snacks, distributing water, children's area, face painting & crafts, entertainment. This event is held at Sherwood Island State Park in Westport, CT--a beautiful location along the Long Island Sound oceanfront.
06880.title: Annual STAR Walk, Roll & Stroll and Family Fun Day

06880.description: CAG is seeking an individual to serve as a Board member who has background in strategic marketing, which ideally includes a blend of marketing planning and execution, with direct experience at an advertising agency or on the client side, with branding, advertising and communications experience. Advocacy experience is also highly regarded. CAG desires assistance to expand its reach, awareness and membership statewide - including further penetration into underserved communities. Also important will be cultivating and maintaining relationships with funders, members, collaborating organizations and legislators as well as the ability to work at a quick pace, flexibly and nimbly. Excellent written and verbal skills are a must. Responsibilities to include the following: Collaborating with the Executive Director and Board leadership to develop and execute a comprehensive marketing and communications plan employing strategies that will broaden programmatic reach and deepen impact, including hands-on experience with all appropriate aspects of social media Managing the ongoing promotion of major programs and developing and executing messaging for new initiatives Identifying and crafting stories that communicate the essence of the organization’s mission and successes Working with the technology-development team to identify a set of meaningful touchpoints with our targets - new member joining, annual pledging - and creating an array of appropriate communications to be automated and sent, in order to stay current and ensure maximum engagement and support from our stakeholders. Working with all CAG committees, specifically including Development and Programming, to assist with execution of their annual plans and to help further corporate engagement efforts Identifying significant media and public policy issues that can be leveraged to support CAG’s work, and creating and implementing plans to exploit them
06880.title: Connecticut Association for the Gifted - BOD Opening in Marketing/Advertising

06880.description: The Connecticut Association for the Gifted (CAG), founded in 1969, is the pre-eminent parent, teacher and school resource and legislative advocate for Connecticut’s talented and high-ability students. CAG provides families with information, resources and programs to benefit their gifted and talented children; educators with high-quality professional development; and Boards of Education with the tools to support talented students. CAG is committed to increasing public awareness statewide that talented and high-ability children exist in all socio-economic, ethnic, and racial groups. CAG also is interested in extending its reach to traditionally underserved populations. CAG is seeking an individual to serve as Treasurer of the Board of Directors. As Treasurer, your responsibilities would be to: Serve as Ex-officio of the Finance and Audit Committee Be an authorized signer on checks and contracts Create and maintain policies related to the budget, audit, investment, financial controls and fiscal management philosophies Lead budget development and monitoring process Prepare reports for Board of Directors meetings on the status of the current budget, investments and any financial issues requiring Board review and/or approval Arrange payment of CAG expenses Train and oversee bookkeeper who: Enters monthly transactions with account and class categorizations into QuickBooks Issues financial reports, as needed Files tax returns annually Distributes 1099s Arrange for annual Financial Review, and provide information to CAG’s public accounting firm Fulfill other duties as assigned by the Board President. This is an unpaid (volunteer) position. To apply or for further information contact Lisa Garner at execdirector@ctgifted.org
06880.title: CAG Board of Director Member to Serve As Treasurer

06880.description: The Connecticut Association for the Gifted (CAG), founded in 1969, is the pre-eminent parent, teacher and school resource, and legislative advocate forConnecticut’s talented and high-ability students. CAG provides families with information, resources and programs to benefit their gifted and talented children; educators with high-quality professional development; and Boards of Education with the tools to support talented students. CAG is seeking an individual to serve as a Board member who has a hands-on background in public relations, including firsthand social media experience. The ideal candidate would possess a working knowledge of strategic marketing that includes a blend of media relations, marketing planning and advocacy. CAG desires assistance to expand its reach, awareness and membership statewide -- including further penetration into underserved communities. Also important will be cultivating and maintaining relationships with funders, legislators and collaborating organizations, as well as the ability to work at a quick pace, flexibly and nimbly. Must also possess excellent written and verbal skills. Responsibilities to include the following: Identifying and crafting stories that communicate the essence of an organization’s mission and successes Collaborating with the Executive Director and Board leadership to develop and execute a comprehensive communications plan employing strategies that will broaden programmatic reach and deepen impact Developing and refining \"core\" organizational messages to ensure consistency across all platforms Identifying significant media and public policy issues that can be leveraged to support CAG’s work, and creating and implementing plans to exploit them Managing messaging for ongoing promotion of major programs and developing messaging for new initiatives Along with ED and officers, representing organization at public events, conferences, workshops, networking groups and media events Developing and supporting relationships with CT media Working with all appropriate committees including Development and Partnership, to assist with corporate/small business/like-minded organization engagement efforts Serving as Executive Editor for the organization's website Along with Program Coordinator, overseeing organizational response to inquiries about CAG Coaching and supporting all staff and board members as spokespersons Previous experience on a non-profit board is helpful This is an unpaid (volunteer) position. To apply or for further information contact Lisa Garner at execdirector@ctgifted.org.
06880.title: Connecticut Association for the Gifted - Board of Directors Member Experienced in Public Relations

10040.description: The Friendly Visiting Program pairs volunteers with home bound seniors to provide company and friendship. We provide friendly visitors to seniors that resides from North 110th street and West of Fifth Avenue to the Northern tip of Manhattan. One visit per week for a minimum of six months can make a difference in a senior’s life. Friendly Visiting Coordinator Elissette Reyes De Jesus 212-342-9694 646-228-1812 ereyesdejesus@isabella.org
10040.title: Friendly Visiting Program
10040.org: Isabella Geriatric Center Friendly Visiting Program

10043.description: 2018: Sixteenth Annual Drums Along the Hudson A Native American and Multicultural Celebration Sunday, June 3rd, 2018- Inwood Hill Park 11am to 6pm - Rain or Shine. FREE The 16th Annual DRUMS ALONG THE HUDSON(r): A Native American and Multicultural Celebration will take place on Sunday, June 3rd, 2018 in Upper Manhattan’s Inwood Hill Park from 11:00 am until 6:00 pm, rain or shine. This event is free to the public and is presented by Lotus Music & Dance in collaboration with the New York City Department of Parks & Recreation, sponsored in part by the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs and the New York City Councilmember Ydanis Rodriguez. The host for the event will be Sandra Bookman, weekend anchor for WABC-TV and host of \"Here and Now\". The afternoon host will be Patrick Riley Pop Culture Expert/Blogger. During the day, we take time to honor individuals and organizations for their contributions to environmental and humanitarian causes.
10043.title: "Drums Along the Hudson: A Native American & Multicultural Celebration"

10044.description: The Matchmaker 5K Run/Walk 2018 Join us on Saturday May 5, 2018, at Firefighters Field, Roosevelt Island for The Icla da Silva Foundation's 8th Annual Matchmaker 5K Run/Walk! This annual event is a fun-filled family-friendly day for all ages and abilities. Come enjoy views of Manhattan and the East River while supporting patients with leukemia and lymphoma and other diseases treatable with a marrow transplant. With your support potential marrow donors are added to the Be The Match Registry and patients receive the care and support services they need for a second chance at life. Volunteer Roles This event would not be possible without the help of our committed volunteers! Volunteer areas include: Operations: Volunteers will help with logistics and operations. Potential responsibilities include: helping with set-up and break-down of the event. Assistance will also be needed with bibs and timing chips distribution. Registration: Volunteers will help with 5k registration, assisting pre-registered runners and race day runners. Hospitality: Volunteers will help greet runners/walkers upon arrival and direct them to the registration area. Assistance will also be needed with bags check-in and runner refreshment at the finish line. Photography/Videography: Volunteers will help capture all the special moments. Family Friendly Activities: Volunteers will help with activities including cheer stations, and face painting. Volunteer Schedule of Events 7:00 am: Volunteers Arrive- Overview; Light Breakfast 7:30 am: Set-up Begins- Route Markers, Signage, Water Stations, Registration, Food Station, Marrow Drive Station, Village Activities 8:30 am: Participants Arrive/Volunteers in Place- Bags Check In, T-Shirt Distribution, Registration, Bibs and Timing Chips Distribution, Village Opens 10:00am: Race Starts - Course Marshalls, Cheering Station, and Water Station 12:00 pm: Event Concludes & Breakdown Begins For more information, please contact Renee at Renee@icla.org or 212-593-1807
10044.title: Volunteers Needed for NYC Matchmaker 5K Run/Walk!

10044.description: Purpose: This role supports the New York City Be The Match Walk+Run Local Organizing Committee. The mission of the Local Organizing Committee (LOC) is to provide local support in the fundraising and promotion of the Be The Match Walk+Run event. It is important for each market to have a strong LOC to help broaden the reach of the event. This internship provides the opportunity to experience first-hand the many facets of operating a fundraising event following a national template within the New York City market. Location: Home-based, New York City Key Responsibilities: * Assist with Walk+Run event operations including: data entry, list development, LOC meetings, and other efforts based on the direction provided by the Development Manager. * Communicate with past/former Walk+Run team captains to encourage their team’s participation and fundraising for the 2018 event. * Recruit new participant teams for the 2018 event and encourage team fundraising utilizing Be The Match Walk+Run participant team fundraising tools. * Assist with the event sponsorship program, primarily through ensuring the fulfillment of sponsorship benefits: acknowledging gifts, updating websites and collateral with sponsor logos, providing information to sponsors for their own internal company campaigns. * Research potential sponsors and in-kind donations by soliciting area businesses via email, telephone, and in person. * Act as Secretary for all LOC meetings and send out meeting notes to all members within 2-3 business days. (LOC meetings typically occur evenings and weekends.) * Assist with coordinating the Walk+Run Kick-off community engagement event. * May fulfill an LOC Chair role in the absence of another volunteer. Reports to: Development Manager, Liz Neihart Time Commitment: * May 2018 - October 2018 * Must volunteer a minimum of 120 hours * Flexible working hours, with some evening and weekend commitments Compensation: Unpaid Qualifications and Requirements: * Must be enrolled at an institution of higher learning. There is a 6-month grace period post-graduation. The internship can be for class credit, but that is not required. * Must be willing to work from a home-based office environment connecting remotely with supervisor. * Able to travel locally within the city to meet sponsors, volunteers, and staff. * Self-motivated, strong interest in nonprofit work and belief in community service, strong interpersonal and communication skills, and the ability to work independently and as a member of a team. * Lifting boxes and supplies may be required as part of preparing for event and promotional opportunities. Benefits Provided: Receive an orientation and work under the direction of the Development Manager. Develop time management, writing and communication, leadership, and project management skills. Gain knowledge of fundraising and event logistics. Organization Description: The National Marrow Donor Program (NMDP) and Be The Match (BTM) is the global leader in providing marrow, PBSC, and umbilical cord blood transplants to patients with leukemia, lymphoma, and other diseases. The nonprofit organization matches patients with donors, educates health care professionals, supports patients and their families, and conducts research so more lives can be saved. Be The Match Walk+Run Overview: Be The Match Walk+Run is a fundraising event that helps patients with blood cancers like leukemia find a marrow donor and receive a life-saving transplant. Every four minutes someone is diagnosed with a blood cancer. It can happen to anyone at any time. But so can a cure - a marrow transplant. The cure for blood cancer is in the hands of ordinary people. Most of us won’t have a marrow donor in our family and Be The Match matches volunteer marrow donors with patients who need them. The Be The Match Walk+Run (5K, 1K, and Tot Trot) raises funds to: add more volunteer potential marrow donors to the Be The Match Registry, giving more patients hope for a cure; help patients with uninsured treatment costs; and support continued marrow transplant research.
10044.title: Be The Match Walk+Run Service Intern: New York City

10044.description: The BCAN Walk to End Bladder Cancer is the Bladder Cancer Advocacy Network's national grassroots fundraising and awareness initiatives that help support the BCAN mission: to increase public awareness about bladder cancer, advance bladder cancer research, and provide educational and support services for the bladder cancer community. We need volunteers to help with setup, registration, and maintaining the walk route. Come on out and support a great cause!
10044.title: BCAN Walk to End Bladder Cancer - NYC

10044.description: The National Ovarian Cancer Coalition is holding its first New York City Run/Walk To Break the Silence on Ovarian Cancer on Saturday, May 19th on Roosevelt Island! The NOCC's mission is to work tirelessly to prevent and cure ovarian cancer, and to improve the quality of life for survivors. The Run/Walk increases awareness, honors those affected by ovarian cancer, and raises funds to support the NOCC's national and local programs. Please join us as we welcome over 500 participants as we change the future of ovarian cancer one step at a time. Roosevelt Island is easily accessible by subway, tram and ferry and offers fantastic views of Manhattan, Queens and beyond! Volunteers are needed from 7:00 am to 12 noon. If you can only come for part of that time, please still contact us. We also need some volunteers to come earlier and stay later. Duties include event set-up, managing our designated tents, registration help, course marshalls, and a number of other logistic needs. To apply, please complete the Volunteer form on our event website: https://runwalk.ovarian.org/newyorkcity/Forms/volunteer-application You can add any special information in the Comments field of the application.
10044.title: Volunteers Needed for 1st NYC Run/Walk to Break the Silence on Ovarian Cancer!

10044.description: We are seeking a volunteer for our Friendly Visiting Program to visit a woman who lives on Roosevelt Island. We are looking for someone to visit once per week for a minimum commitment of six months. Please respond with your telephone number, and the best time to reach you! Thank you!
10044.title: Visit a homebound senior on Roosevelt Island

10044.description: Purpose The mission of the Local Organizing Committee (LOC) is to assist with local fundraising and promotion efforts for the Be The Match Walk+Run event. The New York Be The Match Walk+Run takes place in the fall, usually October. This is a leadership opportunity for individuals looking to share or develop their experience in fundraising and community engagement. Key Responsibilities The primary role of the LOC is to lead the fundraising efforts of the Be The Match Walk+Run. The LOC acts as an ambassador of Be The Match to the local community and acts as a local grassroots promotions team. Individual roles vary depending upon current membership/vacancies and volunteers' strengths and skill sets. The ideal LOC structure includes a Chair and members focused on sponsorships, entertainment, registration, team recruitment, in-kind donations, event promotions, and volunteer recruitment. Location Volunteer in the New York area with the local LOC volunteers and staff Development Manager. Time Commitment The LOC is most active in the 5-6 months leading up to an event. LOC volunteers can expect to spend around 15-20 hours a month on committee work, but this can vary by role and based on your own availability. LOC volunteers are expected to attend meetings/conference calls and local promotional events and to work with Be The Match staff in regards to their specific functional area during the planning period and event weekend. Qualifications * Self-motivated, strong interest in fundraising * Willing to talk to people to engage them in the event * Strong interpersonal and communication skills with the ability to work with office tools such as Microsoft Word and Excel Be The Match Walk+Run Overview Be The Match Walk+Run is a fundraising event that helps patients with blood cancers like leukemia find a marrow donor and receive a life-saving transplant. Every four minutes someone is diagnosed with a blood cancer. It can happen to anyone at any time. But so can a cure - a marrow transplant. The cure for blood cancer is in the hands of ordinary people. Most of us won’t have a marrow donor in our family and Be The Match matches volunteer marrow donors with patients who need them. The Be The Match Walk+Run (5K, 1K, and Tot Trot) raises funds to: add more volunteer potential marrow donors to the Be The Match Registry, giving more patients hope for a cure; help patients with uninsured treatment costs; and, support continued marrow transplant research.
10044.title: New York Be The Match Walk+Run Local Organizing Committee

07608.description: If you have an hour or more per week to give, Ascend Hospice welcomes your gifts of time and compassion. Whether you choose to work directly with patients and families or to volunteer in one of many other ways, you can make a profound difference in someone's life, including your own. Volunteers are an integral part of the hospice team. Ascend Hospice serves counties throughout New Jersey. Areas where you are needed include: Atlantic County, Bergen County, Cape May County, Essex County, Hudson County, Mercer County, Middlesex County, Monmouth County, Morris County, North Passaic County, Ocean County, Somerset County, South Passaic County, Burlington County, Camden County and Union County. Sometimes all it takes is a smile or sharing a story to make somone feel important. All Modalities are welcome. Volunteer Opportunities: Companionship Volunteers work directly with patients providing companionship, offering friendly visits, reading to patients, writing letters, offering a gentle touch or sharing a quiet moment. Complementary Volunteers are certified/trained professionals who can provide complementary modalities of reflexologly, music, Reiki, & massage. Ascend Hospice is seeking certified Reiki practioners to serve our end of life population in finding comfort, relaxation and peace during their final time with us. Your assistance is needed with reducing anxiety, relieving pain and providing a safe , comfortable environment. Training provided for volunteers. Reiki Certification is required. Pet Therapy Volunteers provide companionship from our certified therapy dogs. Pet therapy provides numerous benefits like encouraging movement and physical stimulation and it provides mental benefits like socialization, mental stimulation, companionship, and unconditional love. Please consider sharing your loving pet with us and bring some much needed smiles. Pets must be certified as therapy animals by an organization like TDI Therapy Dogs International- see website here http://www.tdi-dog.org/ Music Volunteers are volunteers who specialize in sharing songs or instrumental music with patients and their loved ones. Whether the Music Volunteer is sharing an existing musical skill or playing music via the radio or digital device, the goal is to enhance the quality of life of our patients. Often, regularly scheduled visits are requested, however Music Volunteers may also be asked to provide musical visits on an occasional basis for one patient/family or for a group of patients at a facility as outreach for the local hospice agency. Hospice is built on the philosophy that we care for our patients in mind, body and soul. Craft Volunteers consist of individuals or groups who touch patients in a special way by making lap blankets, shawls, memory bears and other articles for patients to enjoy. Bereavement Volunteers offer support to the families of patients who have passed. During the grieving process the bereavement volunteer can be a valuable resource, especially for those who lack a solid support network. They often make phone calls to check up on family members and also send cards of comfort and care. For more information about our free volunteer training and available opportunities, call our Volunteer Department or visit our website at Ascendhospice.com! We look forward to hearing from you! Please do not contact me with unsolicited services or offers.
07608.title: Hospice Volunteers - Companion, Music, Pet Therapy, Reiki - Teterboro

11226.description: National Step League is step competition program, comprised of over 400 step teams ranging from ages 9 to 21. Our competition series runs from January to June, progressing from State Level to the Regional Level, and ultimately to our Annual National Championship. We will be having our NYC Step Competition on May 26, 2018 comprised of elementary, middle and high school teams, all performing for the chance to win 1st place in their division and claim the title for the National Championship in Atlanta, Georgia in June..
11226.title: NYC Step Show Championship

11226.description: Brooklyn Take Steps is one of the Foundation’s leading fundraising events in the nation. Help make our event a success. We’re making some great improvements to our festival, walk and finish areas. Share this special event with us! Nearly 1 in 200 Americans live each day with Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis, life-changing digestive diseases. Living with these inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) can be painful and isolating. The Crohn's & Colitis Foundation is dedicated to curing Crohn's and colitis, and to improving the quality of life of children and adults affected by these diseases. The Take Steps community also offers a safe, supportive environment for patients and families. Patients connect with others familiar with the ups and downs of IBD, as well as the friends who support their journey. The Foundation has invested almost $300 million in research to date, enabling groundbreaking treatments and greatly enhancing lives. Make a Difference Today! There are four shifts available: volunteers can take as many opportunities to contribute as they wish. Set-up: 11:00am - 5:00pm Unloading supplies Arrange barricades Decorations Signage Assist vendors Festival: 4:30pm - 9:00pm Festival Kick-off Kid Zone Distribute T-shirts, incentives, food informational materials Usher participants Walk Guide & Spirit Crew: 6:00pm - 8:00pm Event Breakdown: 8:00pm - 10:00pm We cannot make it happen without your help! Please contact us if you have more questions.
11226.title: 2018 Brooklyn Take Steps for Crohn’s & Colitis in Prospect Park
11226.org: Crohn's & Colitis Foundation - Greater NY Chapter

11226.description: Did you know, a wish is not simply a wish. Independent research has proven that the impact of a wish improves medical outcomes for wish kids bravely frightening against their illnesses? Last year we granted over 700 wishes in Western and Metro NY. We have a long list of amazing children in Brooklyn waiting for their wishes to be filled. Become a Wish Granting volunteer. Wish Granters grant the child’s one true wish and are essential to our commitment to bring hope, strength and joy to children battling critical illnesses. A wish is not simply a wish. In the fight against critical illness, wishes spark renewed strength and encouragement for every child and family on their journey. A majority of the service is done via phone, email or text. However, to meet the child and their wish family, you will be paired up with another volunteer to meet them in their home. Currently there are many children living in Brooklyn and Bronx waiting for volunteers to help fulfill their wish.
11226.title: Is Brooklyn in the house? We need Wish Granting Volunteers in your area
11226.org: Make-A-Wish Metro New York and Western New York

11226.description: Be our community champion! Community Options seeks business people to help further its mission. Among the goals set for the Business Advisory Council, or COBAC: To assist Community Options staff in its fundraising endeavors, To assist Community Options staff in networking with the business community, To help individuals with disabilities integrate into their communities, To ensure utmost quality in Community Options services, To educate local business owners and the corporate sector about persons with disabilities and the role that the business community can play in their lives, To attain a societal understanding and acceptance of a person with a disability as a productive member of the community. As a member of COBAC in your community, you're our champion! Join us today. Learn more about COBAC here: http://www.comop.org/get-involved/cobac/
11226.title: Business Advisory Council Committee -BKN

07607.description: If you have an hour or more per week to give, Ascend Hospice welcomes your gifts of time and compassion. Whether you choose to work directly with patients and families or to volunteer in one of many other ways, you can make a profound difference in someone's life, including your own. Volunteers are an integral part of the hospice team. Ascend Hospice serves counties throughout New Jersey. Areas where you are needed include: Atlantic County, Bergen County, Cape May County, Essex County, Hudson County, Mercer County, Middlesex County, Monmouth County, Morris County, North Passaic County, Ocean County, Somerset County, South Passaic County, Burlington County, Camden County and Union County. Sometimes all it takes is a smile or sharing a story to make somone feel important. All Modalities are welcome. Volunteer Opportunities: Companionship Volunteers work directly with patients providing companionship, offering friendly visits, reading to patients, writing letters, offering a gentle touch or sharing a quiet moment. Complementary Volunteers are certified/trained professionals who can provide complementary modalities of reflexologly, music, Reiki, & massage. Ascend Hospice is seeking certified Reiki practioners to serve our end of life population in finding comfort, relaxation and peace during their final time with us. Your assistance is needed with reducing anxiety, relieving pain and providing a safe , comfortable environment. Training provided for volunteers. Reiki Certification is required. Pet Therapy Volunteers provide companionship from our certified therapy dogs. Pet therapy provides numerous benefits like encouraging movement and physical stimulation and it provides mental benefits like socialization, mental stimulation, companionship, and unconditional love. Please consider sharing your loving pet with us and bring some much needed smiles. Pets must be certified as therapy animals by an organization like TDI Therapy Dogs International- see website here http://www.tdi-dog.org/ Music Volunteers are volunteers who specialize in sharing songs or instrumental music with patients and their loved ones. Whether the Music Volunteer is sharing an existing musical skill or playing music via the radio or digital device, the goal is to enhance the quality of life of our patients. Often, regularly scheduled visits are requested, however Music Volunteers may also be asked to provide musical visits on an occasional basis for one patient/family or for a group of patients at a facility as outreach for the local hospice agency. Hospice is built on the philosophy that we care for our patients in mind, body and soul. Craft Volunteers consist of individuals or groups who touch patients in a special way by making lap blankets, shawls, memory bears and other articles for patients to enjoy. Bereavement Volunteers offer support to the families of patients who have passed. During the grieving process the bereavement volunteer can be a valuable resource, especially for those who lack a solid support network. They often make phone calls to check up on family members and also send cards of comfort and care. For more information about our free volunteer training and available opportunities, call our Volunteer Department or visit our website at Ascendhospice.com! We look forward to hearing from you! Please do not contact me with unsolicited services or offers.
07607.title: Hospice Volunteers - Companion, Music, Pet Therapy, Reiki - Maywood

07753.description: We're looking to raise funds, awareness, and Bike MS to support the 10,000 people living multiple sclerosis in our NJ Metro Area. Join us as a volunteer to do your part! Rest Stop volunteers liven up our Bike MS route for our cyclists! Assist with rest stop set up, water and snack replenishment, cheering on our cyclists and rest stop breakdown. THIS YEAR WE WANT YOU TO DECORATE OUR REST STOP! Along the route there will be themed rest stops from Mardi Gras to the Royal Wedding. Feel to choose one of our themes or pick your own! Groups are welcome! CHOOSE A SHIFT 7:30 AM - 10:30 AM OR 10:00 AM - 1:30 PM
07753.title: Join the party! Volunteer at our Bike MS Rest Stop in Neptune City!
07753.org: National Multiple Sclerosis Society - New Jersey Metro Chapter

07753.description: We're looking to raise funds, awareness, and Bike MS to support the 10,000 people living multiple sclerosis in our NJ Metro Area. Join us as a volunteer to do your part! Rest Stop volunteers liven up our Bike MS route for our cyclists! Assist with rest stop set up, water and snack replenishment, cheering on our cyclists and rest stop breakdown. THIS YEAR WE WANT YOU TO DECORATE OUR REST STOP! Along the route there will be themed rest stops from Mardi Gras to the Royal Wedding. Feel to choose one of our themes or pick your own! Groups are welcome! CHOOSE A SHIFT 10:30 AM - 1:30 PM OR 1:00 PM - 4:30 PM
07753.title: Join the party! Volunteer at our Bike MS Rest Stop in Neptune City!
07753.org: National Multiple Sclerosis Society - New Jersey Metro Chapter

07753.description: Holisticare Hospice is looking for - Bereavement Volunteers to offer support and compassion to family members once a hospice patient has passed. Volunteers may make phone calls, do in-person visits, help organize or co-facilitate support groups, all with the support and guidance of other hospice team members. Vigil Volunteers typically sit with patients and families during the dying process. A Vigil Volunteer is a presence, compassionate listener, bringer of rituals, still and quiet. They are an invited guest into a most sacred and personal transition. They understand that this transition is physical and spiritual and that each situation or vigil is unique. Vigil Volunteers go to patients when the time of death is near. Their primary concern is the comfort of the patient. If you are available to volunteer in either or both of the above listed capacities we would love to hear from you.
07753.title: Hospice Bereavement & Vigil Volunteers

07753.description: Holisticare Hospice is looking for reiki healers to provide gentle, supportive therapeutic touch to terminally ill hospice patients, either in a home setting or in a nursing facility. Reiki volunteers typically incorporate aromatherapy or essential oils in their practice to further ease and comfort patients. Reiki certification is required. Holisticare Hospice serves Ocean & Monmouth counties and can provide you with opportunities near your home or work place. Massage therapy visits can be made based on your own particular scheduling needs.
07753.title: Reiki Volunteers

07753.description: Holisticare Hospice is seeking volunteers to share their musical talent with our terminally ill patients and their families & caregivers throughout Ocean & Monmouth County. Whatever your musical talent may be, we would love for you to share it with our patients and their families- piano, keyboard, guitar, harp, flute, harmonica, violin, cello, saxophone, bass and singers we are looking for you to provide much needed companionship and solace. If you are interested in providing this special type of therapy and help we would love to hear from you.
07753.title: Music Therapy Volunteers

07753.description: Holisticare Hospice is currently seeking friendly, well-mannered and calm dogs, of all shapes and sizes (and their people!) These special volunteers are needed to provide companionship, comfort, and even some wet kisses to our terminally ill patients and their families. YOU are needed to help them do it! Our opportunities are flexible and based upon your availability. Therapy pet volunteers can serve both patients and families in residential and nursing facilities throughout Ocean & Monmouth counties. Dogs must be certified through Bright & Beautiful or Therapy Dog International. You and your pup will be interviewed and the appropriate documentation processed with both the certifying organization and ours, prior to visiting with patients. Interested pet owners must attend our full volunteer training which fulfills all Medicare requirements for Volunteer Services.
07753.title: Pet Therapy Volunteer

07753.description: Massage Therapy volunteers provide gentle, supportive massage therapy to terminally ill hospice patients, either in a home setting or in a nursing facility. Massage therapy volunteers typically provide 2 to 4 hours of service weekly, incorporating gentle massage techniques to ease and comfort patients. Volunteers will adapt to the needs of patients who may be frail, elderly, or in pain. Some massage therapy volunteers may provide massage or therapeutic touch to family and/or the caregivers of our terminally ill patients. Holisticare Hospice serves Ocean & Monmouth counties and can provide you with opportunities near your home or work place. Massage therapy visits can be made based on your own particular scheduling needs.
07753.title: Massage Therapy Volunteers

07753.description: Can you help transport injured or orphaned wild birds to licensed NJ wild avian (bird) rehabilitators for the Associated Humane Societies animal shelters? Transports are made as needed & volunteers sign up to be on-call & committed for specific days to transport. Spring thru Fall are especially busy times. We are avian ambulance drivers. We pick up the contained birds & drive them directly to the rehabilitation center, usually The Raptor Trust in Millington NJ. We do not have the radio on while driving the birds nor pause for selfies nor to show the stressed bird to anyone. VBTB is the lifeline to recovery for these birds!
07753.title: The Volunteer Bird Transport Brigade (VBTB)

07753.description: Junior volunteers are needed to support clerical functions at Hackensack Meridian at Home Hospice. Volunteers are needed to file paperwork, data entry, collating, and other clerical functions in our office setting. Earn service hours for your community, school, or religious recognitions.
07753.title: Hospice Junior Volunteer Clerical

07753.description: \"No act of kindness, no matter how small, is ever wasted.\" - Aesop By volunteering with Compassus hospice, you have the wonderful opportunity to make meaningful connections with patients and their families. These non-medical visits may take place at an assisted living facility, nursing home, or in the patient’s own home. We work around YOUR schedule- hours and patient visits are based on your availability. Come be the bright spot in someone’s day! What can volunteers do? Make friendly visits to patients in homes and facilities near you Provide caregiver relief and respite Read Listen Share a special talent like music or crafts Administrative support- in our office or from your home computer. Complementary Therapies such as Reiki, Massage, and Pet Therapy (with proper certifications) What do we provide? Free training at a location near year anda time based on your convenience Free health evaluation and TB test Ongoing educational opportunities Social activities and events Flexible scheduling and patient assignments in your area
07753.title: Love to help people? Become a Hospice Volunteer!

07753.description: Hospice pet therapy volunteers are needed to provide pet therapy visits to patients and families throughout Monmouth and Ocean Counties. Pet therapists must be certified and trained.
07753.title: Hospice Pet Therapy Volunteer

07753.description: Volunteers are needed to provide music to hospice patients at bedside throughout Monmouth and Ocean Counties.
07753.title: Hospice Volunteer Musician

07753.description: Reiki practitioners are needed to provide Reiki services to hospice patients in Monmouth and Ocean counties.
07753.title: Hospice Volunteer Reiki Practitioner

07753.description: Volunteers are needed to visit with patients and families in Monmouth and Ocean Counties. Patients reside in homes, hospitals, assisted living facilities, and skilled nursing facilities throughout Monmouth and Ocean Counties. Volunteers decide where to visit and how often but generally an hour or two per week is preferred. Volunteers may visit, read to patients, watch TV, or just sit quietly at bedside.
07753.title: Hospice Volunteer Patient Visitor

07753.description: Volunteers are needed to support clerical functions at Hackensack Meridian at Home Hospice. Volunteers are needed to make phone calls to patients and families, file paperwork, data entry, collating, and other clerical functions.
07753.title: Hospice Volunteer Clerical Support

07753.description: How can you benefit by being a volunteer? Build your resumé - volunteer experience shows proof of motivation, commitment, initiative, dependability, and flexibility Develop interpersonal skills Increase meaning and purpose in your life Experience significant opportunities for growth and development If you are serving field placement or class-required volunteer hours, we are happy to complete any reporting required by your school Connect one-on-one with patients: Visit patients near your school or home Read to patients, engage sensory and emotional memories, assist with life review and activities, give a hand massage Contribute to our patients’ quality of life just by being there We offer you: FREE TB test Extremely flexible assignments - daytime or evening, weekdays or weekends Convenient FREE training that fits your schedule
07753.title: Direct Patient Contact – Perfect for Healthcare Students

07753.description: How can you benefit by being a volunteer? Increase meaning and purpose in your life Feel pride in making an impact Experience significant opportunities for growth and development Be appreciated Be a friendly companion: Visit patients near your school, work, or home Read to patients, engage sensory and emotional memories, assist with life review and activities, give a hand massage Contribute to our patients’ quality of life just by being there We offer you: FREE TB test Extremely flexible assignments - daytime or evening, weekdays or weekends Convenient FREE training that fits your schedule
07753.title: Connect with Hospice Patients One-on-One

07753.description: Substitute tutors needed to help on a regular basis at each of our tutoring locations--Red Bank, Long Branch, Neptune. Tutoring takes place week nights from 6-7:30. This is a great opportunity to make a difference in the life of a child.
07753.title: SUBSTITUTE TUTORS NEEDED!

07753.description: Contact us for more information on working with hospice patients close to where you live. We provide FREE volunteer training for you along with free TB and Rubella/Rubeola testing. Your pet will need to be a certified pet therapy animal. You and your pet will bring joy and love to the lives of our patients and will receive so much love and joy in return!
07753.title: Share your pet's unconditional love with hospice patients!

07753.description: How can you benefit by being a volunteer? Build your resumé - volunteer experience shows proof of motivation, commitment, initiative, dependability, and flexibility Develop interpersonal skills Increase meaning and purpose in your life Experience significant opportunities for growth and development If you are serving field placement or class-required volunteer hours, we are happy to complete any reporting required by your school Two different opportunities for you to experience... Connect one-on-one with patients: Visit patients in facilities in an area near your school or home Read to patients, engage sensory and emotional memories, assist with life review and activities, give a hand massage Contribute to our patients’ quality of life just by being there Join our dynamic office staff: No special skills needed; training provided. Assist with basic clerical work. If you’re comfortable with a computer, you can help with data entry and other more complex tasks. Gain knowledge of healthcare administration. Our office is open Monday - Friday, 8:30am - 5:00pm. We offer you: FREE TB test Extremely flexible assignments - daytime or evening, weekdays or weekends Convenient FREE training that fits your schedule
07753.title: Human Services and Healthcare Internships Available

07753.description: Jesus said, \"the harvest is plentiful, but the workers are few.\" Please consider being a \"worker\" and share the love of God and the hope of the Gospel with disadvantaged children in Monmouth County, NJ. Weekly \"right choices\" Bible classes take place in three locations--Neptune, Long Branch and Red Bank. Time commitment is approx. 2 hours per week. Our greatest need for teachers is for our Red Bank location. Red Bank Bible class takes place on Tuesday evenings from 5-7 pm at Pilgrim Baptist Church. For further information, please call our office at 732-741-7824.
07753.title: BIBLE CLASS TEACHERS/Teacher Assistants

10024.description: Since 2001 DOROT’s prestigious Summer Teen Internship Program has been inspiring high school students to become leaders and give back to the community. Volunteer with a diverse group of socially-conscious high school students to help local seniors connect. The internship is designed to provide students with a minimum of 92 hours of community service. * Documentary Filmaking - Session I * Intergenerational Theater - Session II * Visit seniors in their home * Teach computer skills * Cook and dine with seniors * Plan intergenerational trips to local museums * 104 hours of community service Session 1: June 25 - July 19 (exceptions made for regents exams) Session 2: July 23 - August 16 Apply here: www.dorotusa.org/teenapp Watch a Day in the Life of a DOROT Teen Intern: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jeXyE2YSHCM ''It’s an incredibly fulfilling experience to reach out to the seniors in the community and help them with whatever they need assistance with. It's also an added benefit that, as teen interns, we can build relationships with other teens who love the same service work. -Maude, Summer Teen Intern The DOROT Summer Teen Internship Program is jointly funded by UJA-Federation of New York and the Jim Joseph Foundation. The Jewish Education Project serves as lead operator of the Initiative.
10024.title: Summer Teen Internship Program 2018

10024.description: Digital Grandparents (DGI), We are seeking volunteers to assist older adults with improving their technology skills during our community service program. Volunteers are needed to engage in one -on-one tutoring with older adults on Saturdays from noon to 2 PM. The organization has had 501(c)(3) status since 2010. Send an email to info@dg-inc.org with the subject line \"I want to volunteer\" if you are interested in applying to become a DGI tutor or to learn more about our program.
10024.title: Volunteers - Assist Older Adults  with the Digital World

10024.description: Volunteers at Star tutor students from low-income families who need help with reading, writing, math or other subjects. The students range in age from 2nd to 12th grade, and attend public and parochial schools across the city. About 65% of students come from families where Spanish is the primary language spoken at home. Tutors complete a written application form and interview, and are matched with an appropriate student. Once the tutor is matched, he/she receives an orientation, and then works one-to-one with the same student each week for two hours. The Center is open for tutoring on Mondays and Wednesdays from 3 to 7 pm, and on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays from 3:30 to 6 pm. You do not need to speak Spanish for this position. ***WE CURRENTLY HAVE A NUMBER OF HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS WHO STILL DO NOT HAVE TUTORS! These students need primary help in Math and Science classes. The ability to help with other subjects, such as writing, would be helpful. You can apply now by visiting https://www.goddard.org/grcc/volunteer/starlearning/ and completing the Tutor Application: School Year.
10024.title: Math and Science Tutors Needed for HS Students!

10024.description: We are looking for volunteers who can regularly commit to fighting hunger while providing dignity to the people we serve! We offer flexible volunteer shifts from Tuesdays to Fridays from 9:30 am to 1:00 pm. Volunteers will assist Mobile Food Pantry staff with set-up, food distribution, crowd control management, and clean up. Since launching the program in 2017, we distributed 56,136 pounds of fresh produce and other food items to 3,075 customers from 14 partner sites in Upper Manhattan and the South Bronx. Please contact Maria Perez, NYC Civic Corps Member, via email at mperez@wscah.org for more information about this volunteer opportunity.
10024.title: Mobile Food Pantry Needs Volunteers in Upper Manhattan and South Bronx!

10024.description: Our incredible team of compassionate volunteers join us from a variety of professional backgrounds and disciplines including: emergency medicine, law enforcement, security, nursing, the culinary arts, travel, international peace keeping, aviation, journalism, law, finance, real estate, marketing, magic, mathematics, biology, electrical engineering, computer science, physics, photography, film, theater, and yoga instruction. To provide medical services through CPMU, volunteers must have a valid New York State EMT-B or better certification AND a current CPR card. Do you want to have special experience or skills that can help the unit outside of being an EMT? When filling out the membership application indicate that you are a service member and describe the special set of skills and experience that you have. https://central-park-medical-unit.breezy.hr/p/4eb52d7c081e-volunteer-emergency-medical-technician-nys-emt
10024.title: Volunteer Emergency Medical Technician (New York State EMT)

10024.description: This opportunity is available every night! Excess bread can be combined with other ingredients to create meals to feed the hungry at a nearby food pantry rather than being thrown out. Help us walk with the food that would have been thrown away! We will get bags of bread and walk for this fifteen minute event, and will finish at the Rectory at the Holy Trinity Catholic Church at 213 W 82nd Street. Light Weight: the average total amount of food is 10 lbs. Sign up directly on our website: http://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/calendar
10024.title: Fight Food Waste & Feed the Hungry in Upper West Side 8:05PM-8:20PM

10024.description: Love to knit? crochet? Want to learn more? Join DOROT's knitters and crocheters to create warm blankets for homeless seniors, or those that are at risk. Knitting and Crocheting Afghans for Seniors Gather twice a month with other volunteers to knit or crochet Afghans that will be given to seniors at DOROT’s Homelessness Prevention and Aftercare Program. Wednesdays & Thursdays, 10:30 AM - 12:00 PM 2018 Wednesday, January 3rd Thursday, January 18th Wednesday, February 7th Thursday, February 15th Wednesday,March 7th Thursday, March 15th DOROT will provide some supplies, bringing your own is preferred. For more information and to register, please contact Debbie Weiss, Coordinator of Adult Volunteers at dweiss@dorotusa.org or 917-441-5069.
10024.title: Knitting & Crocheting Afghans for Seniors- Upper West Side

10024.description: Bring the knowledge and skills you've developed to make a significant impact on the lives of older members of our community. Our DOROT seniors will benefit from your time and expertise. You will meet other volunteers and make new friends that share similar interests and are as passionate about volunteering as you. Volunteer Opportunities Inlcude: Cooking for DOROT's Homelessness Prevention Program Knitting Group Intergenerational Programs Vist our website for more information: http://www.dorotusa.org/site/PageServer?pagename=vol_older_adult#.VkEWgLeFNdg
10024.title: Retired, In transition? Volunteer with DOROT to assist seniors.

10024.description: Heat and serve dinner, socialize, and facilitate conversation at DOROT's transitional housing facility. Volunteers are needed Monday and Friday nights. DOROT social workers support you in your volunteer efforts. Interview, training, references, and background check are required responsible and mature volunteers 18
10024.title: Serve dinner &  socialize with seniors at DOROT's transitional housing

10024.description: Escort a senior to a cultural event such as a concert, movie, theater or museum. Interview, training, references and background check is required.
10024.title: Escort a senior to a cultural event

10024.description: Teach basic computer skills and internet navigation to a senior in their home. Lessons are 3-4 sessions, depending on the senior’s needs, for approximately one hour. Interview, training, references and background check are required.
10024.title: Teach computer skills to seniors in Manhattan

10024.description: Make a friend for a lifetime! Visit a senior and forge a new friendship. Enjoy conversation, companionship and share mutual interests. These weekly one hour visits occur within the home of a senior residing on the East Side or Upper West Side of Manhattan. You will be matched by a professional social worker to establish a meaningful and rewarding relationship. A volunteer orientation,interview, training, references, background check and year-long commitment are required.
10024.title: Become a Friendly Visitor with a local senior

10024.description: Help frail seniors with grocery shopping, getting to medical appointments or just taking a walk in the park! Interview, training, references and background check is required.
10024.title: Help seniors with grocery shopping and errands in Manhattan

07601.description: Breakfast and lunch are given to all volunteers. We are gathering volunteers to represent our organization which provides child safety education and helps disadvantaged children. For our involvement our organization receives a $500 donation \"Slam Dunk the Junk\" is a clean-up event that takes place on the last Saturday in April. The event is overseen by the Dept. of Cultural Arts, who are custodians of the Hackensack Clean Communities Grant. This event is designed to gather 501c3 Non Profit organizations together to help clean and remove litter from the streets and waterways of Hackensack. Each organization receives a $500 stipend from Clean Communities for helping remove litter in our area. Clean Communities works closely with the Hackensack Riverkeeper and the Hackensack Board of Education to provide litter-free events throughout the year.
07601.title: Help us clean up a park and help our Child Safety cause
07601.org: The Joan Angela D'Alessandro Memorial Foundation

07601.description: BVMI provides free healthcare to low income Bergen County residents who do not have health insurance or the means to pay for healthcare. We keep our patients out of hospital emergency rooms. Our patients come from many different backgrounds and some of them do not speak English. We are looking for an interpreter for our patients who speak Korean. This will help our patients and doctors communicate more effectively. If you are ready to give back to your community and speak Korean, BVMI is the right place for you. For more information about our organization, please visit www.BVMI.org
07601.title: Interpreter - Korean

07601.description: The Diabetes Foundation Inc is currently seeking an enthusiastic and knowledgeable office administrative volunteer to join our team. As an administrative volunteer you will provide administrative support as well as support DFI’s fundraising efforts.
07601.title: Office Administrative Volunteer

07601.description: The Diabetes Foundation Inc is currently actively seeking an enthusiastic and knowledgeable administrative volunteer to join our team. On the cusp of an exciting new program qualified candidates will aid in day to day activities of the organization. Candidates will possess experience in: Microsoft Suite (Word, PowerPoint, Excel, and Publisher) Mailings Database organization and cleanup. Friendly phone presence General familiarity in office setting
07601.title: Administrative Volunteer

07601.description: BVMI provides free primary healthcare to low-income Bergen County residents who do not have health insurance. We are looking for volunteer doctors, physician assistants and other healthcare professionals to treat our patients. PCPs are especially welcome, but specialists are always needed to practice at BVMI, either in our office and/or for us to refer to. All volunteers must have a valid license to practice in NJ. BVMI provides free malpractice insurance to those doctors seeing patients in our office at 75 Essex Street.
07601.title: Volunteer Physician /Physician Assistant - On-Site

07601.description: BVMI provides free primary healthcare to low-income Bergen County residents who do not have health insurance. Our patients lack the means to pay for medical care; BVMI keeps our patients out of local Emergency Departments. Our patients come from many different backgrounds and some of them do not speak Spanish. We are looking for an interpreter for our patients who speak Spanish. This will help our patients and doctors communicate more effectively. If you are ready to give back to your community and speak Spanish, BVMI is the right place for you. For more information about BVMI, please visit www.bvmi,org.
07601.title: Interpreter - Spanish

07601.description: BVMI provides free primary healthcare to low-income Bergen County residents who do not have health insurance. Our patients lack the means to pay for medical care; BVMI keeps our patients out of local Emergency Departments. Healthcare professionals are at the heart of BVMI. A team of 65 volunteer physicians, nurses and other medical scribes provide medical care for BVMI’s patients. Our scribes specialize in charting physician-patient encounters during medical exams. If you are a student getting ready to attend medical school or presently in medical school and are looking for experience, BVMI is the right place for you. This volunteer position offers one-on-one collaboration with a physician and is unprecedented in terms of exposure to real medicine in practice. Our scribes learn about patient care on the job in real time. The center is open Monday - Friday, 9am - 5pm. Thursday we are open until 7pm and we are flexible in terms of how often and how much time you spend at BVMI Our patients come from many different backgrounds; please let us know if you are bilingual (Spanish, Korean, Chinese, etc). For more information about BVMI, please visit www.bvmi,org.
07601.title: Medical Scribe

07601.description: Volunteers needed to represent BVMI at community fairs throughout Bergen County. We will train and provide information about BVMI for distribution.
07601.title: Community Fair Representative
